paper_title: Mesoporous In(OH)3 for photoreduction of CO2 into renewable hydrocarbon fuels

catalyst.source: Mesoporous In(OH)3 for photoreduction of CO2 into renewable hydrocarbon fuels
catalyst.context: Mesoporous In(OH)3 for photoreduction of CO2 into renewable hydrocarbon fuels

catalyst.source: Indium hydroxide (In(OH) 3 ) with mesoporous structure has been synthesized via a sol-gel hydrothermal treatment.
catalyst.context: Indium hydroxide (In(OH) 3 ) with mesoporous structure has been synthesized via a sol-gel hydrothermal treatment.The phase compositions, optical properties, and morphologies of the photocatalysts were systematically investigated via powder X-ray diffraction, UV-visible absorption spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, chemisorption analyzer and transmission electron microscopy.The theoretical calculation based on density functional theory demonstrated that the potentials of valence band and conduction band of In(OH) 3 are both suitable for CO 2 photoreduction.The photocatalytic efficiencies of the samples were characterized by testing the photoreduction of CO 2 to CH 4 under full-arc Xe lamp irradiation.The sample modified with mesoporous structure is about 20 times higher in efficiency than that of sample without mesoporous structure, which is attributed to the outstanding structure characteristics in higher surface area and strong adsorption of the mesoporous structure.

catalyst.source: In a typical process, In(OH) 3 powder (0.2 g) loaded with Pt (0.5 wt.) by the in situ photo-deposition method 8 was uniformly dispersed in a glass reactor with an area of 8.5 cm 2 .
catalyst.context: The photocatalysts were prepared by a sol-gel hydrothermal synthesis (see Scheme S1).All of the reagents were analytical grade and used without further purification.In a typical synthesis, 5 mmol of In(NO 3 ) 3 4.5H 2 O was mixed with 30 mL of ethylene glycol (EG) (99,Wako Co., Japan).After stirring for 10 min, 20 mL of isopropanol (Wako, 99) was dropped into the solution and then the solution was heated it at 80 C until totally volatilized to obtain a white gel.After milling the gel completely, the obtained powders were mixed with 80 mL distilled water, and then the mixture was poured into 120 mL of Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave.This autoclave was heated up to 180 C and kept for 36 h.The obtained precipitate was washed with distilled water for several times and dried at room temperature overnight. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were characterized by a RIGAKU Rint-2000 X-ray diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromatized Cu-K radiation ( 1.54178A).Scanning electron microscopy images and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy patterns were recorded with a JEOL 6700F field emission scanning electron microscopy.Transmission electron microscopy and high-resolution were performed with a JEOL 2100F field emission transmission electron microscopy operated at 200 kV.The pulsed adsorption of CO 2 was recorded with a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2930 chemisorption analyzer.Here the powder samples were pretreated at 150 C in Ar for 1 h before the pulsed adsorption of CO 2 .UV-visible diffuse reflectance spectrum was recorded with a Shimadzu UV-2500 Spectrophotometer.The measurements of surface area were carried out in a BELSORP II Surface Area Analyzer. The electrical structure was calculated by the DFT with the CASTEP program.Electronic structure of the In(OH) 3 was investigated via the plane-wave-pseudopotential approach based on the density functional theory (DFT).Geometry optimization model was performed to determine the most stable structure.Then its electronic structure was calculated using a standard Cambridge serial total energy package (CASTEP) code 3,4.The electron-core interaction was represented via ultrasoft pseudopotentials with a plane-wave basis cutoff energy of 340 eV.The electronic exchangecorrelation energy was treated within the frame-work of the local density approximation (LDA).The self-consistent field (SCF) tolerance was all 1 10 -6 eV/atom. A 300 W Xe arc lamp was used as the light source.The reaction was performed in a gas-closed system with a gas-circulated pump (see Fig. S4).The volume of the reaction system was about 360 mL.In a typical process, In(OH) 3 powder (0.2 g) loaded with Pt (0.5 wt.) by the in situ photo-deposition method 8 was uniformly dispersed in a glass reactor with an area of 8.5 cm 2 .Deionized water (2-3 mL) was injected into the reaction system as reductive agent.The reaction system was vacuum-pumped and washed with high purity CO 2 gas for several times.Then high purity CO 2 gas was introduced into the reaction system to achieve 80 KPa.During the irradiation, about 0.5 mL of gas was sampled from the reaction system at given intervals for subsequent CH 4 concentration analysis with a gas chromatograph (GC-14B, Shimadzu Corp., Japan).

catalyst.source: A facile and effective approach was developed to synthesize In(OH) 3 with mesoporous structure which achieved enhanced activity in CO 2 photoreduction.
catalyst.context: A facile and effective approach was developed to synthesize In(OH) 3 with mesoporous structure which achieved enhanced activity in CO 2 photoreduction.As-prepared In(OH) 3 samples loaded with co-catalysts could efficiently convert CO 2 into CH 4 under UV light irradiation.The evolution rate of CH 4 over the mesoporous In(OH) 3 is about 0.8 mol(g h) -1 , which is 20 times higher than that of n-In(OH) 3 (0.04 mol(g h) -1 ).Moreover, the totally adsorption of CO 2 on mesoporous In(OH) 3 is about 0.479 cm 3 g -1 which is about 4 times higher than that of n-In(OH) 3 (0.113 cm 3 g -1 ).It's proved that the mesoporous structure is advantageous for the photocatalytic activities of CO 2 reduction.Furthermore, the theoretical calculation of the band structure shows that the dispersion of the density of states is advantageous for the electrons generation and transmission.The mesoporous In(OH) 3 for photoreduction of CO 2 into renewable hydrocarbon fuels is reported for the first time.This work will provide useful information for further study on morphology controlling to enhance the photocatalytic efficiency of photocatalysts. Fig. 1.XRD pattern of mesoporous In(OH)3 (i); The standard data for In(OH)3 (JCPDS NO. 73-1810) (ii). Fig. 2. (a) SEM image;(b,c) High and low magnification of HRTEM image of mesoporous In(OH)3; (d) nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution (inset); (e-g) FE-SEM images of In(OH)3 obtained at 180 C for (e) 1 h, (f) 10 h,and (g) 36 h. 93 V, vs. NHE, pH 5 9.The conduction band (CB) position can be deduced by E CB E VB -E g .Therefore, the band edge of conduction band (E CB ) is -0.93 eV (vs NHE).Moreover, the potential of CB of In(OH) 3 is more negative than that of E 0 (CO 2 /CH 4 ) CO 2 8e - 8H CH 4 2H 2 O E 0 (CO 2 /CH 4 ) -0.24 V, vs. NHE, pH 5.As above analysis, the photogenerated electrons and holes can react with the adsorbed CO 2 and H 2 O to produce CH 4 . Fig. 3. SEM images of assembled crystals during in the synthesis process (a,b) 1 h, (c,d) 3 h and (e) the schematic diagram of growth process of mesoporous structure. Fig. 4. DFT calculation of In(OH)3: (a) energy band dispersion and (b) density of states. Fig. 5. (a) CH4 evolution over In(OH)3 with various co-catalysts under full-arc Xe lamp irradiation.(co-catalysts: Pt, 0.5 wt.);(b) SEM images and nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of In(OH)3 synthesized from aqueous solution of ammonia (inset SEM (i) and curve (i)) and mesoporous In(OH)3 (inset SEM (ii) and curve (ii));. Fig. 6.The Pulsed Adsorption of CO2 on (a) mesoporous In(OH)3 and (b) nonmesoporous In(OH)3 (n-In(OH)3). A 300 W Xe arc lamp was used as the light source.The reaction was performed in a gas-closed system with a gas-circulated pump (see Fig. S4).The volume of the reaction system was about 360 mL.In a typical process, In(OH) 3 powder (0.2 g) loaded with Pt (0.5 wt.) by the in situ photo-deposition method 8 was uniformly dispersed in a glass reactor with an area of 8.5 cm 2 .Deionized water (2-3 mL) was injected into the reaction system as reductive agent.The reaction system was vacuum-pumped and washed with high purity CO 2 gas for several times.Then high purity CO 2 gas was introduced into the reaction system to achieve 80 KPa.During the irradiation, about 0.5 mL of gas was sampled from the reaction system at given intervals for subsequent CH 4 concentration analysis with a gas chromatograph (GC-14B, Shimadzu Corp., Japan).
